content.body: I meant that it would be `let foo @ [let head, ...let tail]`
content.formatted_body: I meant that it would be let foo @ [let head, ...let tail]

content.body: That just looks confusing. If we wanted to use a one character token we could just replace `and` with `&` and write `let foo & [let head, ...let tail]` or `[let head, ...let tail] & let foo` interchangeably
content.formatted_body: That just looks confusing. If we wanted to use a one character token we could just replace and with & and write let foo & [let head, ...let tail] or [let head, ...let tail] & let foo interchangeably

content.body: the issue is that there isn't usually a notion of "and" in pattern matching, but there is a notion of "pinning" or "as patterns" or whatever you want to call it
i.e. `[let head, ...let tail] as let foo` would be fine too, it just fixes it to be after instead of before
content.formatted_body: i.e. [let head, ...let tail] as let foo would be fine too, it just fixes it to be after instead of before

content.body: this is what I'm saying when I say "conjoin[ing] a binding with another subpattern ... is ironically the place where `and` feels like a confusing word choice"
content.formatted_body: this is what I'm saying when I say "conjoin[ing] a binding with another subpattern ... is ironically the place where and feels like a confusing word choice"

content.body: if we need to have `and`, then yes, we don't need another thing for `@` / `as`, but I have never thought of `@` / `as` as being `and`-like
content.formatted_body: if we need to have and, then yes, we don't need another thing for @ / as, but I have never thought of @ / as as being and-like

content.body:
> <@rkirsling:matrix.org> the issue is that there isn't usually a notion of "and" in pattern matching, but there is a notion of "pinning" or "as patterns" or whatever you want to call it

I have seen `and` patterns about as often as I've seen pinning patterns
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @rkirsling:matrix.org
the issue is that there isn't usually a notion of "and" in pattern matching, but there is a notion of "pinning" or "as patterns" or whatever you want to call it
I have seen and patterns about as often as I've seen pinning patterns

content.body: I'm not saying `@` or `as` are `and` like, but that I believe `and` should exist independently, and there's no reason to have two different tokens that could just be a single token. Comparing `A and B and let c` vs `A and B @ let c`, the `@` feels like it could also just be `and`.
content.formatted_body: I'm not saying @ or as are and like, but that I believe and should exist independently, and there's no reason to have two different tokens that could just be a single token. Comparing A and B and let c vs A and B @ let c, the @ feels like it could also just be and.

Comparing `A and B and let c` vs `A and B @ let c`, the `@` feels like it could also just be `and`.
